Authors:
Marcela Castilho Boro, Ana Lucia Jesus, Jose Ivanildo de
Souza, Agostina Virginia Marano, Carmen Lidia Amorim
Pires-Zottarelli
Title:
Molecular identification of Pseudozyma aphidis: first record
from a Brazilian mangrove swamp
Keywords:
Atlantic rainforest, Basidiomycota, ITS, yeast-like
fungi
Abstract:
Pseudozyma aphidis is an anamorph yeast-like basidiomycete
commonly found as saprotroph in vegetable debris, such as leaves and
flowers. However, there are reports of this species as pathogenic in
humans, usually occurring in patients with some type of
immunosuppression that predisposes opportunistic infections. Specimens
of this species were collected from water samples and Rhizophora mangle
L. leaves at different salinities along the Perequê River. This river is
located in a mangrove swamp area at “Parque Estadual da Ilha do
Cardoso”, Cananéia municipality, São Paulo State, Brazil. Aliquots of
these samples were spread in Petri dishes. The samples baited with
cataphiles of Allium cepa L. were incubated for 7 days at 21 º C. After
incubation, the baits were observed under the microscope and the
specimens were isolated and purified. These specimens were identified
based on the phylogenetic analysis of the ITS rDNA region. This is the
first record of this species in São Paulo State.
